issue.title: PQ ciphers in pyopenssl and cryptography
issue.body: Hello, first off this is not an issue but a question. I have been working with pqopenssl for a while now but currently, I am working on a project that would need PQ integration with pyopenssl and cryptography (Python). How should I go about doing this?

comment.body: Hello -- thanks for your interest in/use of OQS. First off, can I safely assume you saw https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-python and it doesn't provide what you need? If so, could you help me understand what you cannot do with the presently available "set of things" (liboqs -> oqs-py-binding and oqs-openssl -> app-level support like [curl](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-demos/tree/master/curl) )? Do you "simply" want to establish TLS 1.3 QSC connections from within Python? If so, did you try oqs-curl with http://pycurl.io/docs/latest/index.html ? Just a thought, I also didn't try that yet.

issue.title: PQ ciphers in pyopenssl and cryptography
issue.body: Hello, first off this is not an issue but a question. I have been working with pqopenssl for a while now but currently, I am working on a project that would need PQ integration with pyopenssl and cryptography (Python). How should I go about doing this?

comment.body: Hello, thank you for your reply. Yes, I did check out the python liboqs but that does not really help with what I am trying to do. The project is to include post-quantum ciphers in QUIC (An internet protocol alternative to TCP/TLS). It does use TLS 1.3 but I am trying to figure out how python cryptography and python OpenSSL can be modified to interpret PQ ciphers.

issue.title: PQ ciphers in pyopenssl and cryptography
issue.body: Hello, first off this is not an issue but a question. I have been working with pqopenssl for a while now but currently, I am working on a project that would need PQ integration with pyopenssl and cryptography (Python). How should I go about doing this?

comment.body:
Thanks for the background. This looks like you'd need a pretty "deep" integration of TLS and QUIC state machines for which there is arguably much better support in C (e.g., [QUIC in curl](https://daniel.haxx.se/blog/tag/quic/) ) -- assuming (quantum-safe) functionality is more important than use of Python. Otherwise, why don't you build off https://pypi.org/project/aioquic/ ? 

But then again, this is your project and I wouldn't want/can't define the direction your work should take. Suffice it to say that our work was intended to show QSC-integration into a TLS engine -- without necessarily the goal to make the result ready-to-use for "language-specific" state-machine integrations with other protocols.

issue.title: Adds spring2020 OQS algs
issue.body:
Adds latest OQS algorithms. Addresses issue #194.

##### Checklist
- [X] Add KEMs
- [ ] Add sigs

comment.body:
Reading the chain above makes me wonder whether it wouldn't be sensible to add things like this to the README (say in a 'supported algs' subsection) saying why certain things are _not_ supported (McEliece b/o size; Leda b/o vulnerability; others?), maybe with an issue to resolve it?

Advantage: Others also know about this (and in an ideal world maybe offer help resolving the issues).

issue.title: PQ ciphers in pyopenssl and cryptography
issue.body: Hello, first off this is not an issue but a question. I have been working with pqopenssl for a while now but currently, I am working on a project that would need PQ integration with pyopenssl and cryptography (Python). How should I go about doing this?

comment.body: Thank you for your reply. I am building from aioquic but I am just not sure where to start integrating. It uses openssl so I am just thinking linking pip to OQS-OpenSSL should do the trick right?

issue.title: Added BoringSSL interoperability tests.
issue.body:
I've also added a new CircleCI job for BoringSSL interop-testing. Presently it's not a nightly-only job, but I'll change it to be nightly-only once the PR is approved.

I also haven't added a README for these tests, since I'm considering breaking them out into a separate "interoperability testing" repository once we're done with this release cycle.

comment.body:
> > I didn't find CMS interop tests: Does it also have no capabilities (apparently like s2n) for this?
> 
> Judging from the things tested [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl/blob/master/crypto/pkcs7/pkcs7_test.cc), it seems BoringSSL supports PKCS7 insofar as it applies to certificates. It certainly does not have a full fledged tool like `openssl cms`, as seen [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl/tree/master/tool).

OK - one thing less to test interop of :) But certs I'd argue we should check (or create an issue as to be something that should be tested).

issue.title: Undefined references
issue.body:
When i try to 
`cmake --build build`
I get  following error
```
[ 98%] Linking C executable example_kem
../lib/liboqs.a(fips202x4.c.o): In function `shake256x4.constprop.0':
fips202x4.c:(.text.shake256x4.constprop.0+0x3013): undefined reference to `KeccakP1600times4_PermuteAll_24rounds'
fips202x4.c:(.text.shake256x4.constprop.0+0x47b1): undefined reference to `KeccakP1600times4_PermuteAll_24rounds'
../lib/liboqs.a(fips202x4.c.o): In function `PQCLEAN_KYBER512_AVX2_shake128x4_squeezeblocks':
fips202x4.c:(.text.PQCLEAN_KYBER512_AVX2_shake128x4_squeezeblocks+0x54): undefined reference to `KeccakP1600times4_PermuteAll_24rounds'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
gmake[2]: *** [tests/example_kem] Error 1
gmake[1]: *** [tests/CMakeFiles/example_kem.dir/all] Error 2
gmake: *** [all] Error 2
```
Strangely, I can build the lib on another machine. I suspect that openssl may be the problem, since on the compiling machine
```
$ openssl version
OpenSSL 1.1.1c FIPS  28 May 2019
```
The machine that has problems compiling
```
$ openssl version
OpenSSL 1.1.1c  28 May 2019
```
It seems to miss the FIPS module, thus also the problem in fips202... file. I build OpenSSL 1.1 manually from source on the problematic machine. I have checked liboqs.a by `nm` on both the machines and they seem to contain identical symbols.

Since LibOQS switched to OpenSSL 1.1+, there is no FIPS module available (afaik is expected in OpenSSL 3.0). If my assumptions are correct, then OQS will not be runable on distros without packaged OpenSSL with vendor-provided FIPS module.

I have tried numerous workarounds yet the error is always the same (and always on the far far side of linking phase).

comment.body:
Just to be clear, the problem persists even if I configure via
```
cmake -Bbuild -H. -DOQS_USE_OPENSSL=OFF -DOQS_USE_SHA2_OPENSSL=OFF -DOQS_USE_SHA3_OPENSSL=OFF -DOQS_USE_AES_OPENSSL=OFF 
```

issue.title: Undefined references
issue.body:
When i try to 
`cmake --build build`
I get  following error
```
[ 98%] Linking C executable example_kem
../lib/liboqs.a(fips202x4.c.o): In function `shake256x4.constprop.0':
fips202x4.c:(.text.shake256x4.constprop.0+0x3013): undefined reference to `KeccakP1600times4_PermuteAll_24rounds'
fips202x4.c:(.text.shake256x4.constprop.0+0x47b1): undefined reference to `KeccakP1600times4_PermuteAll_24rounds'
../lib/liboqs.a(fips202x4.c.o): In function `PQCLEAN_KYBER512_AVX2_shake128x4_squeezeblocks':
fips202x4.c:(.text.PQCLEAN_KYBER512_AVX2_shake128x4_squeezeblocks+0x54): undefined reference to `KeccakP1600times4_PermuteAll_24rounds'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
gmake[2]: *** [tests/example_kem] Error 1
gmake[1]: *** [tests/CMakeFiles/example_kem.dir/all] Error 2
gmake: *** [all] Error 2
```
Strangely, I can build the lib on another machine. I suspect that openssl may be the problem, since on the compiling machine
```
$ openssl version
OpenSSL 1.1.1c FIPS  28 May 2019
```
The machine that has problems compiling
```
$ openssl version
OpenSSL 1.1.1c  28 May 2019
```
It seems to miss the FIPS module, thus also the problem in fips202... file. I build OpenSSL 1.1 manually from source on the problematic machine. I have checked liboqs.a by `nm` on both the machines and they seem to contain identical symbols.

Since LibOQS switched to OpenSSL 1.1+, there is no FIPS module available (afaik is expected in OpenSSL 3.0). If my assumptions are correct, then OQS will not be runable on distros without packaged OpenSSL with vendor-provided FIPS module.

I have tried numerous workarounds yet the error is always the same (and always on the far far side of linking phase).

comment.body:
So, I played around with some switches and eventually made it work by disabling
```OQS_USE_CPU_EXTENSIONS```
I will keep the issue active since I believe there is some mistake in the switch logic that breaks the build, I suspect `OQS_USE_BMI2_INSTRUCTIONS` and so on, yet it is beyond my understanding.
The "broken" machine /proc/cpuinfo flags:
```
flags		: fpu vme de pse tsc msr pae mce cx8 apic sep mtrr pge mca cmov pat pse36 clflush dts mmx fxsr sse sse2 ss syscall nx pdpe1gb rdtscp lm constant_tsc arch_perfmon pebs bts nopl xtopology tsc_reliable nonstop_tsc aperfmperf eagerfpu pni pclmulqdq ssse3 fma cx16 pcid sse4_1 sse4_2 x2apic movbe popcnt tsc_deadline_timer xsave avx f16c rdrand hypervisor lahf_lm abm epb invpcid_single fsgsbase tsc_adjust bmi1 avx2 smep bmi2 invpcid xsaveopt dtherm ida arat pln pts
```
The "working" machine /proc/cpuinfo flags:
```
flags		: fpu vme de pse tsc msr pae mce cx8 apic sep mtrr pge mca cmov pat pse36 clflush mmx fxsr sse sse2 ht syscall nx rdtscp lm constant_tsc rep_good nopl xtopology nonstop_tsc cpuid tsc_known_freq pni pclmulqdq ssse3 cx16 pcid sse4_1 sse4_2 x2apic movbe popcnt aes xsave avx rdrand hypervisor lahf_lm abm 3dnowprefetch invpcid_single fsgsbase avx2 invpcid rdseed clflushopt md_clear flush_l1d arch_capabilities
```

issue.title: Adding BoringSSL/curl?
issue.body:
Would it be an idea to create a BoringSSL-based curl image, too? This might make interop testing easier (ensuring matching curve config files, e.g.). I'd be happy to do that, probably building on the present curl version (using openssl to create certs if bssl doesn't have that). I'd give it a try using the new curl-dev image #29 . Side benefit: I'd learn a bit about using BoringSSL...

@xvzcf : Sensible? Useless? Any comment welcome.

comment.body: On the whole this sounds good; the one thing to keep in mind is that BoringSSL offers no API or ABI stability, which means we'd have to be a bit careful when changing the Curl/BoringSSL versions used in the demo. Right now I want to anchor BoringSSL to Chromium and am still looking into that. Perhaps once that's set we can look at building Curl with BoringSSL.

issue.title: fixing speed crash in AES
issue.body:
Fixes: 

> OpenSSL internal error: assertion failed: (length % AES_BLOCK_SIZE)

Tests ran OK at https://circleci.com/gh/baentsch/openssl/tree/mb-fixaesspeed

comment.body: Is it important to have multiple of 1024? I picked the original value randomly-ish. Should there be a logic to the value with end up using?
